la.text: In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.

en.text: In the beginning was the Word and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.

la.text: Hoc incipit Deo et officium omnis monachi fidelis sit cantante humilitate iterare immutabilem eventum cuius certissima veritas affirmari potest.

en.text: This was beginning with God and the duty of every faithful monk would be to repeat every day with chanting humility the one never-changing event whose incontrovertible truth can be asserted.

la.text: Videmus autem nunc per speculum et in aenigmate; et veritas, antequam coram cunctis exhibetur, se praebet in fragmentis (heu, ut implicatos!), in errore mundi, ut debeamus describere fidelia signa eius, etiam cum recondita nobis videantur quasique miscentia voluntate ad malum omnino directa.

en.text: But we see now through a glass darkly, and the truth, before it is revealed to all, face to face, we see in fragments (alas, how illegible) in the error of the world, so we must spell out its faithful signals even when they seem obscure to us and as if amalgamated with a will wholly bent on evil.

la.text: Cum pervenirem finem pravae vitae meae, capillo meo cano, inveterasco ut mundus, expectans ut perdam me in infinito abysso silentii et deserti numinis, habens in partemm luminis angelicarum sapientiarum; inclusus nunc, gravi aegrotoque corpore meo, in cella cari monasterii Melk, praeparo in membrana scribere testimonium mirabilium terribiliumque eventuum quos in iuventute observavi, verbatim nunc iterans omnia quae vidi audivique, non audens aliquam interpretationem signa signorum reliquere eis qui post me venient (si Antichristus prius non venit), ut precatio invenientis eis exerceatur.

en.text: Having reached the end of my poor sinner’s life, my hair now white, I grow old as the world does, waiting to be lost in the bottomless pit of silent and deserted divinity, sharing in the light of angelic intelligences; confined now with my heavy, ailing body in this cell in the dear monastery of Melk, I prepare to leave on this parchment my testimony as to the wondrous and terrible events that I happened to observe in my youth, now repeating verbatim all I saw and heard, without venturing to seek a design, as if to leave to those who will come after (if the Antichrist has not come first) signs of signs, so that the prayer of deciphering may be exercised on them.

la.text: Deus concedat mihi gratiam ut sim testis fidelis eventuum qui acciderunt in abbatia cuius nominem in praesens solum rectum piumque est omittere, circa finem anni Domini nostri MCCCXXVII, cum Imperator Louis in Italiam descenderet ut dignitatem Imperii Sancri Romani restitueret, ita consilia Omnipotentis retinens et nefarium usurporem, confundens simonium haereticumque qui in Avignone sacro nomini apostoli verecundiam attulit (pravam animam Jacques de Cahors refero, quem Johannes XXII impii venerabanur).

en.text: May the Lord grant me the grace to be the transparent witness of the happenings that took place in the abbey whose name it is only right and pious now to omit, toward the end of the year of our Lord 1327, when the Emperor Louis came down into Italy to restore the dignity of the Holy Roman Empire, in keeping with the designs of the Almighty and to the confusion of the wicked usurper, simoniac, and heresiarch who in Avignon brought shame on the holy name of the apostle (I refer to the sinful soul of Jacques of Cahors, whom the impious revered as John XXII).

la.text: Forte, ut faciam eventus multo intellectos in quibus implicatum me inveni, ea quae accidebant annis postremis saeculi huius revocare debeo, ut tunc comprehendi ea, per ea vivens, et ut nunc reminiscor ea, perfecta aliis fabulis quas postea audivi—si adhuc memoria mea fila nimium perturbatorumque eventuum conectere potest.

en.text: Perhaps, to make more comprehensible the events in which I found myself involved, I should recall what was happening in those last years of the century, as I understood it then, living through it, and as I remember it now, complemented by other stories I heard afterward—if my memory still proves capable of connecting the threads of happenings so many and confused.

la.text: Papa Clemens V, in principo saeculi, apostolicam sedem ad Avignon transtulerat, relinquens Romam praedam ambitionibus dominorum urbis: Sacra Urbs Christianitae paulatim in circum versa erat, aut in lupanar, certaminibus inter duces discissa; republica appellata tamen non erat, et armatiorum manibus oppugnabatur, violentiae direptionique exposita.

en.text: In the early years of that century Pope Clement V had moved the apostolic seat to Avignon, leaving Rome prey to the ambitions of the local overlords: and gradually the holy city of Christianity had been transformed into a circus, or into a brothel, riven by the struggles among its leaders; though called a republic, it was not one, and it was assailed by armed bands, subjected to violence and looting.

la.text: Eludentes saecularem iurisdictionem, clerici manus malorum ducebant atque, malam mercaturam violantes et disponentes, gladio in
compilabant.

en.text: Ecclesiastics, eluding secular jurisdiction, commanded groups of malefactors and robed, sword in hand, transgressing and organizing evil commerce.

la.text: Quomodo poterat prohibere ne Caput Mundi fierit rursus, et recte, meta viri qui coronam Imperii Sancri Romani habere volebat et dignitatem imperii temporalis restituere qui ad Caesaribus pertinuerat?

en.text: How was it possible to prevent the Caput Mundi from becoming again, and rightly, the goal of the man who wanted to assume the crown of the Holy Roman Empire and restore the dignity of that temporal dominion that had belonged to the Caesars?

la.text: Itaque in MCCCXIV, in Frankfurt, quinque princeps Germanii Ludovicum Bavariium maximum imperatorem imperii legaverunt.

en.text: Thus in 1314 five German princes in Frankfurt elected Louis the Bavarian supreme ruler of the empire.

la.text: Eodem die autem, in adverso litore Mainis fluvii dux Palatine de Rhine et archiepiscopus Colognii in idem maximum officium Federicum de Austria legaverunt.

en.text: But that same day, on the opposite shore of the Main, the Count Palatine of the Rhine and the Archbishop of Cologne elected Frederick of Austria to the same high rank.

la.text: Unum solium duobus imperatibus et unus papa duobus: res erat quae, vere, magnam inordinationem concitaret. ...

en.text: Two emperors for a single throne and a single pope for two: a situation that, truly, fomented great disorder. ...

la.text: Duobus annis postea, in Avignon, novus papa delegabatur: Ioannes de Cahors, duoseptuaginta annorum senex qui, ut supra dixi, nomen Ioannis XXII cepit; ne autem caelum patiatur nulum papam iterum capere hoc nomen quod nunc tam odiousum probis sit.

en.text: Two years later, in Avignon, the new Pope was elected, Jacques of Cahors, an old man of seventy-two who took, as I have said, the name of John XXII, and heaven grant that no pontiff take again a name now so distasteful to the righteous.

la.text: Gallus vir, regi galliae devotus, (viri huius terrae corruptae inclinati semper sunt fovere delectationes sui populi atque non possunt totum mundum suam domum animi considerare), sustinuerat "Pulchrum Philippum" contra Equites Templares, quos rex accusavit (iniuste credo) de flagitiosissimis facinoribus ut, cum conscientia huius repulsi ecclesiastici, bona eorum rapieret.

en.text: A Frenchman, devoted to the King of France (the men of that corrupt land are always inclined to foster the interests of their own people, and are unable to look upon the whole world as their spiritual home), he had supported Philip the Fair against the Knights Templars, whom the King accused (I believe unjustly) of the most shameful crimes so that he could seize their possessions with the complicity of that renegade ecclesiastic.

la.text: In MCCCXXII Ludovicus Bavariium suum adversarium Federicum vicit.

en.text: In 1322 Louis the Bavarian defeated his rival Frederick.

la.text: Timens unum imperatorem etiam plus quam duos, Johannes victorem excommunicavit, qui in vices Papam hereticum detulit.

en.text: Fearing a single emperor even more than he had feared two, John excommunicated the victor, who in return denounced the Pope as a heretic.

la.text: Debeo nunc revocare quomodo, ipso anno, Franciscalium collegium in Perugiae convocatum sit, atque princeps eius, Michele de Cesena, accipiens preces Spiritualium (de quibus loquar), paupertatem Christi veritatem fidei pronuntiaverit, qui, si quid cum apostolis possedisset, usus facti solum possederat.

en.text: I must also recall how, that very year, the chapter of the Franciscans was convened in Perugia, and the minister general, Michael of Cesena, accepting the entreaties of the Spirituals (of whom I will have occasion to speak), proclaimed as a matter of faith and doctrine the poverty of Christ, who, if he owned something with his apostles, possessed it only as usus facti.

la.text: Digna sententia erat, habita in animo virtutem et puritatem ordinis defendere, Papam autem nimis displicebat, qui fortasse in sentencia scrutavit principium quod ipsas postulationes periclitetur quas, ut caput ecclesiae, fecerat, negans imperio potestatem deligendorum episcoporum, atque, contrario, affirmans solium pontificis ius imperatoris inaugurandi habere.

en.text: A worthy resolution, meant to safeguard the virtue and purity of the order, it highly displeased the Pope, who perhaps discerned in it a principle that would jeopardize the very claims that he, as head of the church, had made, denying the empire the right to elect bishops, and asserting on the contrary that the papal throne had the right to invest the emperor.

la.text: Motus his aut alteris rationibus, in MCCCXXIII, decreto "Cum inter nonnullos" propositiones Franciscalium Johannes condemnavit.

en.text: Moved by these or other reasons, John condemned the Franciscan propositions in 1323 with the decretal Cum inter nonnullos.

la.text: Statim, puto, Franciscanos, nunc inimicos pontificis, socios futuros suos Loduvicus vidit.

en.text: It was at this point, I imagine, that Louis saw the Franciscans, now the Pope’s enemies, as his potential allies.

la.text: Affirmantes paupertatem Christi, notiones magistrorum theologiae imperii aliqua confirmabant, id est Marsilii de Padue et Johannis de Jandun.

en.text: By affirming the poverty of Christ, they were somehow strengthening the ideas of the imperial theologians, namely Marsilius of Padua and John of Jandun.

la.text: Tandem autem, non pluribus mensibus prioribus eventibus quos narro, Ludovicus victo Federico pactum statuit, in Italia descendit, et in Milano coronabatur.

en.text: And finally, not many months before the events I am narrating, Louis came to an agreement with the defeated Frederick, descended into Italy, and was crowned in Milan.

la.text: Sicut res erant cum ego—iuvenis Benedictinus monachus monasterii Melkii—ex pace claustri removerem ab patre meo pugnante cum Ludovico, non minimo apud eius principes.

en.text: This was the situation when I—a young Benedictine novice in the monastery of Melk—was removed from the peace of the cloister by my father, fighting in Louis’s train, not least among his barons.

la.text: Putavit ducere me cum eo prudens esse ut miracula Italiae sciarem atque cum imperator coronaretur ibi essem.

en.text: He thought it wise to take me with him so that I might know the wonders of Italy and be present when the Emperor was crowned in Rome.

la.text: Verum obsidio Pisae bellicis rebus eum occupavit.

en.text: But the siege of Pisa then absorbed him in military concerns.

la.text: Relictus solus, inter urbes Tuscanii peregrinatus sum, partim propter otium atque partim otium desiderium cognoscendi.

en.text: Left to myself, I roamed among the cities of Tuscany, partly out of idleness and partly out of a desire to learn.

la.text: Sed hae indisciplinata libertas, mei patres putaverunt, adoslescenti devoto vitae otii non apta erat.

en.text: But this undisciplined freedom, my parents thought, was not suitable for an adolescent devoted to a contemplative life.

la.text: Tunc sequentes consilium Marsilii, cui placui, sub praeceptione sapientis Franciscani locare me constituerunt, fratis Gulielmi de Baskerville, qui initiabat officium quod ad urbes celebres et abatias antiquas eum ducat.

en.text: And on the advice of Marsilius, who had taken a liking to me, they decided to place me under the direction of a learned Franciscan, Brother William of Baskerville, about to undertake a mission that would lead him to famous cities and ancient abbeys.

la.text: Ita cum scriba tum discipulus Gulielmi factus sum, nec numquam eo dolui, quia cum eo testis fui dignorum eventorum scribendorum, ut iam facio, cunctis qui post nos venirent.

en.text: Thus I became William’s scribe and disciple at the same time, nor did I ever regret it, because with him I was witness to events worthy of being handed down, as I am now doing, to those who will come after us.

la.text: Ignorabam tunc quid frater Guilelmus quaereret, et quoque vere, hodie etiam id ignoro, et puto eum ipsum id ignoravisse; motus sicut erat solum desiderio veritatis atque suspicione—quam potui videre eum semper excipere veritatem non esse quae ei videbatur aliquo momento.

en.text: I did not then know what Brother William was seeking, and to tell the truth, I still do not know today, and I presume he himself did not know, moved as he was solely by the desire for truth, and by the suspicion—which I could see he always harbored—that the truth was not what was appearing to him at any given moment.

la.text: Fortasse atque illis annis ex suis amatis studiis distractus erat saecularibus officiis.

en.text: And perhaps during those years he had been distracted from his beloved studies by secular duties.

la.text: Officium quod Guilelmus praeceptus erat ignotum mihi erat dum in itinere eramus, aut, immo, numquam de eo locutus est cum me.

en.text: The mission with which William had been charged remained un-known to me while we were on our journey, or, rather, he never spoke to me about it.

la.text: Cum partes colloquiorum cum abbatibus monasteriorum ubi requivimus in itenere audivissem, aliquam notionem naturae huius officii feci.

en.text: It was only by overhearing bits of his conversations with the abbots of the monasteries where we stopped along the way that I formed some idea of the nature of this assignment.

la.text: Sed non copiose id comprehendi donec ad terminum nostrum advenimus, ut nunc narrabo.

en.text: But I did not understand it fully until we reached our destination, as I will tell presently.

la.text: Terminus noster septentrionalis erat, sed iter nostrum linea cum recta non sequebatur, atque in pluribus abbatiis quievimus.

en.text: Our destination was to the north, but our journey did not follow a straight line, and we rested at various abbeys.

la.text: Ita accidit ut ad occidentem verteremus cum terminus noster orientalis esset, paene sequentes
quod ducit ex Pisa ad

peregrinorum itineris ad Jacobem, requiescentes in loco quem non nomino quod terribiles eventuus qui ibi acciderunt me dissuadent, sed cuius principes fideles imperio erant, et ubi abbaticus ordinis nostri, cuncti in consensu, hereticum corruptumque Pontificem opponebant.

en.text: Thus it happened that we turned westward when our final goal was to the east, almost following the line of mountains that from Pisa leads in the direction of the pilgrim’s way to Santiago, pausing in a place which the terrible events that took place there dissuade me from identifying more closely now, but whose lords were liege to the empire, and where the abbots of our order, all in agreement, opposed the heretical, corrupt Pope.

la.text: Iter nostrum, inter plures vicissitudines, duas septimanas mansit, atque hoc
opportunitatem habui magistrum meum novum cognocere (numquam satis, persuasus remaneo).

en.text: Our journey lasted two weeks, amid various vicissitudes, and during that time I had the opportunity to know (never enough, I remain convinced) my new master.

la.text: In paginis sequentibus, descriptiones personarum non indulgebo--nisi expressio faciei, aut gestus, quasi signum linguae
sed eloquentis videretur--quia, ut Boethius inquit, nihil celerius est quam forma externa, quae ut flores
pallent mutantque cum autumnus
; atque cur hodie referat dicere abbaticum Abo severum oculum et pallidas genas habere, quia iam is et ii circum eum pulvis sunt atque corpora sua mortalem glaucum pulveris habent (solae animae, Deo
, fulgent
quae numquam

en.text: In the pages to follow I shall not indulge in descriptions of persons—except when a facial expression, or a gesture, appears as a sign of a mute but eloquent language—because, as Boethius says, nothing is more fleeting than external form, which withers and alters like the flowers of the field at the appearance of autumn; and what would be the point of saying today that the abbot Abo had a stern eye and pale cheeks, when by now he and those around him are dust and their bodies have the mortal grayness of dust (only their souls, God grant, shining with a light that will never be extinguished)?

la.text: Tamen, describere Guilelmum saltem semel velim, quoniam singularia lineamenta eius me percusserunt, atque viro seniori
coniuctum fieri typicum
est, non solum
et acumine mentis sed etiam sui
multa cara probat, quasi ut figura patris, cuius
exploramus atque cuius frontium contractionesque  risas 1. In principio erat Verbum, et Verbum erat apud Deum, et Deus erat Verbum.

en.text: But I would like to describe William at least once, because his singular features struck me, and it is characteristic of the young to become bound to an older and wiser man not only by the spell of his words and the sharpness of his mind, but also by the superficial form of his body, which proves very dear, like the figure of a father, whose gestures we study and whose frowns, whose smile we observe—without a shadow of lust to pollute this form (perhaps the only that is truly pure) of corporal love.

la.text: viri formosi magnique erant (iam ei pueri pumilionesque sunt), sed id tantum est una multarum rerum qua cladem/calamitatem cani/senecti mundi ostendit.

en.text: In the past men were handsome and great (now they are children and dwarfs), but this is merely one of the many facts that demonstrate the disaster of an aging world.

la.text: Puer non plus aliquem studere volat, eruditio/doctrina in diminutione est, cunctus mundus in suo capite ambulat, caeci caecos ducunt
in profundidate mergant, volucres ante volare possunt nidum fugiunt, asinus lyram canitque bos saltat.

en.text: The young no longer want to study anything, learning is in decline, the whole world walks on its head, blind men lead others equally blind and cause them to plunge into the abyss, birds leave the nest before they can fly, the jackass plays the lyre, oxen dance.

la.text: Maria vitam otii no plus amat et Martha vitam industriae no plus amat, Leah sterilis est, Rachel oculum corpore abit, Cato lustra visit, et Lucretius feminam fit.

en.text: Mary no longer loves the contemplative life and Martha no longer loves the active life, Leah is sterile, Rachel has a carnal eye, Cato visits brothels, Lucretius becomes a woman.

la.text: Omnia in prava via sunt.

en.text: Everything is on the wrong path.

la.text: Illis diebus, Deo
, ab domino/magistro meo desiderium discere/
et prudentiam rectae viae, qua in tortuosis itineribus etiam remanet, acquisivi.

en.text: In those days, thank God, I acquired from my master the desire to learn and a sense of the straight way, which remains even when the path is tortuous.

la.text: Illo tempore aspectus physicus Fatris Guilelmus talis erat qualis observantiam minime attenti attraxit.

en.text: Brother William’s physical appearance was at that time such as to attract the attention of the most inattentive observer.

la.text: Altitudo eius illam hominis normalis exsuperabat atque tam tenuis erat quam etiam grandior videbatur.

en.text: His height surpassed that of a normal man and he was so thin that he seemed still taller.

la.text: Oculi eius acres penetralesque erant; tenuis et leviter rostratus nasus
hominis
dabat, praeter
de
loquar.

en.text: His eyes were sharp and penetrating; his thin and slightly beaky nose gave his countenance the expression of a man on the lookout, save in certain moments of sluggishness of which I shall speak.

la.text: et Northumbriam saepe vidi--per ocassionem haesitationem dubitationemque poterat efferre.

en.text: His chin also denoted a firm will, though the long face covered with freckles—such as I often saw among those born between Hibernia and Northumbria—could occasionally express hesitation and puzzlement.

la.text: Ad postremum intellexi curiositatem esse quod inopia confidenciae videbatur; sed in principio
cognoscebam, quam magis passionem concupiscentis animae putavi.

en.text: In time I realized that what seemed a lack of confidence was only curiosity, but at the beginning I knew little of this virtue, which I thought, rather, a passion of the covetous spirit.

la.text: Credidi animam rationalem talem pasionem indulgere non debere, sed ab
solum nutriri, quam (putabam) homo statim cognoscit.

en.text: I believed instead that the rational spirit should not indulge such passion, but feed only on the Truth, which (I thought) one knows from the outset.

la.text: Ut puer eram, primum, et racemos pilorum flavorum eiectos ex eius auribus, atque crassa rufa supercilia penitissime miratus sum.

en.text: Boy that I was, I was first, and most deeply, struck by some clumps of yellowish hair that protruded from his ears, and by his thick blond eyebrows.

la.text: Quinquaginta
fortasse viderat, igitur atque senex erat, tamen infatigabile corpus eius cum agilitate
ego ipse carebam movebat.

en.text: He had perhaps seen fifty springs and was therefore already very old, but his tireless body moved with an agility I myself often lacked.

la.text: Cum
eum
, vis eius
videbatur.

en.text: His energy seemed inexhaustible when a burst of activity overwhelmed him.

la.text: Sed a tempore usque ad tempus, ut sua vitalis anima quoddam
habebat, in tempore
iacebat, atque in culcita cellae
per multas horas eum iacere spectabam, paucas syllabas vix
, et singulum musculum faciei/vultus non

en.text: But from time to time, as if his vital spirit had something of the crayfish, he moved backward in moments of inertia, and I watched him lie for hours on my pallet in my cell, uttering barely a few monosyllables, without contracting a single muscle of his face.

la.text: absensque expressio in oculis appareabat, et suspicatus essem eum sub
alicuius vegetabilis substantiae
esse, si manifesta temperantia eius vitae me ut repudiarem illam cogitationem non

en.text: On those occasions a vacant, absent expression appeared in his eyes, and I would have suspected he was in the power of some vegetal substance capable of producing visions if the obvious temperance of his life had not led me to reject this thought.

la.text: Non negabo, tamen, eum in
, aliquando in
, in
, ad colligendum aliquam herbam (
semper, credo) conquiescere; et tunc cum absorto
eam manducare.

en.text: I will not deny, however, that in the course of the journey, he sometimes stopped at the edge of a meadow, at the entrance to a forest, to gather some herb (always the same one, I believe): and he would then chew it with an absorbed look.

la.text: Semper aliquem secum retineabat, atque in temporibus maximae contentionis eam edebat (et in
habuimus!).

en.text: He kept some of it with him, and ate it in the moments of greatest tension (and we had a number of them at the abbey!).

la.text: Quondam, cum quid esset
, ridens locutus est bonum
de infideles aliquando discere posse, atque cum peterem
me eam gustare sineret, respondit
quae seni
bonae sint, puero
non bonas esse.

en.text: Once, when I asked him what it was, he said laughing that a good Christian can sometimes learn also from the infidels, and when I asked him to let me taste it, he replied that herbs that are good for an old Franciscan are not good for a young Benedictine.

la.text: Nobis
normalem/regularem vitam ducere non potuimus: etiam in abbatia exsomnes
remanebamus et lassis
cecidimus, praeterea in officio divino/liturgia horarum regulariter non participavimus.

en.text: During our time together we did not have occasion to lead a very regular life: even at the abbey we remained up at night and collapsed wearily during the day, nor did we take part regularly in the holy offices.

la.text: In itinere, vero, postquam completoriam
rare vigilabat et eius mores frugales erant.

en.text: On our journey, however, he seldom stayed awake after compline, and his habits were frugal.

la.text: Interdum, in abbatia quoque, totum
ambulans in
inspectans ut si chrysoprasi aut smaragdi essent; atque circa
vagantem inveni,
chrysoprasis smaragdisque ornatam videntem ut si racimus "daturae stramonii" esset.

en.text: Sometimes, also at the abbey, he would spend the whole day walking in the vegetable garden, examining the plants as if they were chrysoprases or emeralds; and I saw him roaming about the treasure crypt, looking at a coffer studded with emeralds and chrysoprases as if it were a clump of thorn apple.

la.text: In alis temporibus, totum diem in magno
impedat, libros spectans ut si nihil sed suam ipsius delectationem quaerens (dum, circum nos, cadavera
, atrociter
, multiplicabant).

en.text: At other times he would pass an entire day in the great hall of the library, leafing through manuscripts as if seeking nothing but his own enjoyment (while, around us, the corpses of monks, horribly murdered, were multiplying).

la.text: rationem de suis operibus reddere non deberet.

en.text: One day I found him strolling in the flower garden without any apparent aim, as if he did not have to account to God for his works.

la.text: In ordine meo, multo dispariorem modum temporis
me
dixi.

en.text: In my order they had taught me quite a different way of expending my time, and I said so to him.

la.text: mundi non solum de unitate in diversitate, sed etiam de diversitate in unitate venire.

en.text: And he answered that the beauty of the cosmos derives not only from unity in variety, but also from variety in unity.

la.text: Quod mihi visum est explicatio ducta ab sensu
esse, sed postea didici
eius terrae
saepe circumscribere in modis in quibus illuminantem vim
officium
habere videbatur.

en.text: This seemed to me an answer dictated by crude common sense, but I learned subsequently that the men of his land often define things in ways in which it seems that the enlightening power of reason has scant function.

la.text: In tempore nostro in abbatia, eius
cum pulve
obductae semper erant, atque cum auro adhuc recentium
, aut cum flavis rebus quas in infirmaria Severini tangebat.

en.text: During our period at the abbey his hands were always covered with the dust of books, the gold of still-fresh illumination, or with yellowish substances he touched in Severinus’s infirmary.

la.text: Videbatur eum praeter
cogitare non posse, attributionem quae propria
tum me videbat: sed etiam cum
fragilissimas
, ut quasdam nuper-illuminatos
, aut
et tam friabiles quam azymes panes, mihi videbatur eum tactum delicatissimum habere, eundem quo utebatur cum machinas tangeret.

en.text: He seemed unable to think save with his hands, an attribute I considered then worthier of a mechanic: but even when his hands touched the most fragile things, such as certain freshly illuminated codices, or pages worn by time and friable as unleavened bread, he possessed, it seemed to me, an extraordinarily delicate touch, the same that he used in handling his machines.

la.text: Narrabo, vero,
quomodo rarus vir
quae non prius videram, quae mirabiles machinas appellabat, in sacculo cum se gesserit

en.text: I will tell, in fact, how this strange man carried with him, in his bag, instruments that I had never seen before then, which he called his wondrous machines.

la.text: Machinae, dicebat,
artis sunt,
imitator naturae est, atque illae non formas naturae sed ipsas
recreant.

en.text: Machines, he said, are an effect of art, which is nature’s ape, and they reproduce not its forms but the operation itself.

la.text: Itaque mirabilia horologi, astrolabii, et magnetis mihi explicavit.

en.text: He explained to me thus the wonders of the clock, the astrolabe, and the magnet.

la.text: In principio vero, timebam
maleficae
essent, atque quibusdam splendis noctibus dormire simulabam cum

en.text: But at the beginning I feared it was witchcraft, and I pretended to sleep on certain clear nights when he (with a strange triangle in his hand) stood watching the stars.

la.text: quos in Italiaque mea
cognoveram viri simples, saepe illitterati, erant, atque admirationem meam eius eruditionis ei dixi.

en.text: The Franciscans I had known in Italy and in my own land were simple men, often illiterate, and I expressed to him my amazement at his learning.

la.text: Ridens respondit vero
suae insulae in dispari
formatos esse: "Roger Bacon, quem ut magister meus admiror, docet ut consilium
scientiam machinae uno die comprehendat, quae naturalis sanaque magica ars est.

en.text: But he said to me, smiling, that the Franciscans of his island were cast in another mold: “Roger Bacon, whom I venerate as my master, teaches that the divine plan will one day encompass the science of machines, which is natural and healthy magic.

la.text: Atque uno die, utenda vi naturae
erit,
creare quibus naves unico homine regente procedent, atque
ociores quam
velis
impulsae; atque

erunt 'ut sine animali moveantur cum impetu inaestimabili, et instrumenta volandi et homo sedens in medio instrumenti revolvens aliquod ingenium per quod alae artificialiter compositae aerem verberent, ad modum avis volantis.'

en.text: And one day it will be possible, by exploiting the power of nature, to create instruments of navigation by which ships will proceed unico homine regente, and far more rapid than those propelled by sails or oars; and there will be self-propelled wagons ‘and flying apparatuses of such form that a man seated in them, by turning a device, can flap artificial wings, ad modum avis volantis.

la.text: Parvissima instrumenta magna
levabunt, atque vehicula in produndis oceanorum ire permittent."

en.text: And tiny instruments will lift huge weights and vehicles will allow travel on the bottom of the sea."

la.text: Cum ubi machinae essent interrogavi, respondit eas iam
atque etiam aliquas in tempore
factas esse: "Praeter instrumentum
, quod numquam vidi et aliquem qui id viderit non cognovi, sed eruditum qui id cogitavit cognosco.

en.text: When I asked him where these machines were, he told me that they had already been made in ancient times, and some even in our own time: “Except the flying instrument, which I have never seen or known anyone who has seen, but I know of a learned man who has conceived it.

la.text: Atque pontes sine columnis aut alio stabilimento fieri possunt, et aliae inauditae machinae possibiles sunt.

en.text: And bridges can be built across rivers without columns or other support, and other unheard-of machines are possible.

la.text: Vero si etiam non essent, non molestare debes, quoniam non significat eas in futuro non futuras esse.

en.text: But you must not worry if they do not yet exist, because that does not mean they will not exist later.

la.text: Te dico Deum eas esse velle, atque in Eius mente iam sunt, etiam si amicus meus de Occam negat talia cogitata existere; quod non dico quia divinam naturam determinare possumus, sed immo quia finem
constituere non possumus."

en.text: And I say to you that God wishes them to be, and certainly they already are in His mind, even if my friend from Occam denies that ideas exist in such a way; and I do not say this because we can determine the divine nature but precisely because we cannot set any limit to it."

la.text: Nec ea erat sola contradictio
eum proferre audivi; sed etiam nunc, cum senex sapientiorque sum, non adhuc intellexi quomodo tantam fidem in amico eius de Occam habere posset atque simul in verba Baconi juraret, ut consuescebat.

en.text: Nor was this the only contradictory proposition I heard him utter; but even now, when I am old and wiser than I was then, I have not completely understood how he could have such faith in his friend from Occam and at the same time swear by the words of Bacon, as he was accustomed to doing.

la.text: Veritas est quod, in illis tenebrosis temporis, sapiens credere debebat in rebus quae in contradictione inter se erant.

en.text: It is also true that in those dark times a wise man had to believe things that were in contradiction among themselves.

la.text: Illic id est: de fratre Guilelmo res sine ratio fortasse dixi,
de ipso principio diiunctas impressiones quas de eo habui tunc colligam.

en.text: There, of Brother William I have perhaps said things without sense, as if to collect from the very beginning the disjointed impressions of him that I had then.

la.text: Qui esset, atque qui faceret, mei care lector, de actibus quae  perfecit in diebus nostri in abbatia forsitan meior colliges.

en.text: Who he was, and what he was doing, my good reader, you will perhaps deduce better from the actions he performed in the days we spent in the abbey.

la.text: Nec artificiosam descriptionem, sed, magis, narrationem eventuum (quidem illos) mirabiles formidulososque promitto te.

en.text: Nor do I promise you an accomplished design, but, rather, a tale of events (those, yes) wondrous and awful.

la.text: Itaque, postquam de die in diem meum magistrum cognosueram, atque multas horas nostri itineris diuturnis colloquiis, quas paulatim narrabo, consumpseram, ad collem in quo abbatia stabat perveniebamus.

en.text: And so, after I had come to know my master day by day, and spent the many hours of our journey in long conversations which, when appropriate, I will relate little by little, we reached the foot of the hill on which the abbey stood.

la.text: Tempus rectus est quod narratio mea, ut tunc faciebamus, ad collem appropinquet, atque mea manus stabilis maneat ut narrare quid acciderit praeparo.

en.text: And it is time for my story to approach it, as we did then, and may my hand remain steady as I prepare to tell what happened.
